   history of CAD s/p CABG x 4, recent NSTEMI in [**11-4**], HTN, sCHF (EF
   25-30% prior to this admission) who had VT arrest.
   .
# Brain injury: Per neuro:
patient has irreversible hypoxic-ischemic [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) **]
[**Last Name (un) **] as well as a large brain infarct that was embolic.
  Patient was found down
 in rehab, unclear how long pt was out before she was shocked.  Patient was on a
rctic sun cooling protocol for 18hrs, and has been off sedation since [**12-31**] early
AM.  EEG shows global suppression, but given pt was on versed and in the presenc
e of renal failure, may need to wait until sedation completely wears off before
final neuro status and neurologic prognosis determined.  On the night of [**12-31**], pa
tient was noted to have anisocoria (right pupil 4mm minimally reactive to light,
 left pupil 2mm reactive to light), concerning for herniation.  Repeat CT head w
ith EEG leads on showed large MCA stroke.  Patient has no brainstem reflexes.
   - f/u on neuro recs
   - hyperventilation to reduce ICP, goal pCO2 27-30
   - keep HOB at 30 degree
   - hold off on mannitol given acute renal failure, acidosis, and
   hypotension
   - continue aspirin, plavix, statin
   - per patient's daughters, patient stated that she would not want to
   "live like vegetable"
   - will discuss with family today re withdrawal of care as there is no
   realistic expectation that pt will ever recover from this brain injury
   .
   # C. Diff colitis: Patient had diarrhea at rehab, and levofloxacin on
   admission did not help. It is very possible that when she was cooled,
   the c-diff pooled and was delivered in a large bolus upon rewarming.
   Patient was started on antibiotics for c.diff on [**12-31**], KUB in the
   evening of [**12-31**] shows evidence of early toxic megacolon. Pt meets the
   surgical indication for colectomy but not a surgical candidate given
   her brain injury and stroke.
   - continue PO vanc 500 mg q6, IV flagyl 500 mg q8 Flagyl
   - KUB stable, can hold off on serial KUBs
   - serial q4 abdominal exams
   - follow WBC and fever curves
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Patient with baseline Cr 1.4-1.5, admitted with
   Cr of 3.3 in context of poor PO intake on lisinopril and
   spironolactone, dirty U/A and c.diff infection which likely started
   when she was in rehab. Urine lytes suggestive of pre-renal etiology;
   creatinine improved to 2.4 with hydration. However, creatinine worsened
   on [**12-31**] with no UOP despite IVF boluses. Urine showed muddy brown casts,
   consistent with ATN.  UA consistent with pre-renal etiology.  No urine
   eos.  The etiology is multifactorial and related to sepsis/cdiff,
   intravascular dryness, and pressors.  UOP minimally responded to IVF
   boluses, low dose dopamine.  No HD will be initiated given poor neuro
   status.
   - f/u renal recs
   - trend lytes and renal function [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue to treat c.diff as above
   - continue to hold spironolactone & lisinopril
   .
   # Septic shock: likely secondary to c.diff infection.  Patient required
   pressor support with dopamine (up to 7) which increased with warming.
   The pressor was switched to Norepi (0.04) on [**2131-12-30**], switched to neo on
   [**12-31**] for tachycardia.  With multi-organ failure, including kidney,
   liver, and brain.
   - continue to wean her down on pressor
   - NS bolus prn
   - Holding ACEI and spironolactone and lasix for now
   - continue to treat c.diff as above
   - maintain MAP goal 60
   - cV02 goal >70%
   - follow lactate
   .
   # VF/VT Arrest: No strips from rehab, but was shocked by AED twice.
   Most likely etiologies for VF/VT arrest is renal failure/hyperkalemia,
   ischemia after NSTEMI in [**11-4**], and heart failure with EF 15-20%. 18
   hour Artic sun protocol commenced on [**2131-12-29**] AM, and completed at [**2131-12-30**]
   at 12 noon. TTE performed on [**2131-12-29**] demonstrated an EF of 15-20%, with
   akinesis of the LV inferior wall and basal to mid hypokinesis
   elsewhere, though the inferior wall akinesis was seen on prior ECHO on
   [**11-4**], likely representing stunned myocardium.
   - wean pressors as tolerates
   - will likely withdraw care today
   - no meaningful recovery will occur for ICD placement
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis: Both anion gap (gap 15) and non-anion gap
   metabolic acidosis (delta-delta <1).  Anion gap acidosis is likely from
   lactate acidosis and starvation ketone acidosis.  Non-anion gap
   acidosis is likely from diarrhea and NS she received yesterday. pH
   7.35, from hyperventilation on the vent.
   - continue hyperventilation on vent, keep pCO2 27-30
   - continue bicarb gtt at 75cc/hr
   - will likely withdraw care
   .
   # Coagulopathy: rising PT, PTT an INR.  Fibrinogen normal, less
   concerning for DIC.  Could be due to liver injury, however LFT is not
   terribly abnormal.   Also could be secondary to starvation and vitK
   deficiency.
   - hold off on IV vitK
   - continue to trend
   - will give FFP if actively bleeding
   - heparin sc discontinued, pneumoboots on for DVT ppx
   .
   # Liver dysfunction: LFT rising. AST, alk phos and LDH abnormal.
   Likely due to hepatic congestion, less likely shock liver since LFTs
   are not very high.
   - treat sepsis as above
   - continue to monitor
   - no RUQ US for now given this is most likely secondary to sepsis
   .
   # Leukocytosis with bandemia: secondary to c.diff.  UTI contributes to
   it as well. CXR no evidence of pneumonia.
   - continue to treat c.diff as above
   - f/u all cultures
   - continue to trend WBC and fever curve
   .
   # Lactic Acidosis: improving; related to low cardiac output and
   pressors. Feet are clearly hypoperfused (bilaterally)
   - continue to follow
   - NS boluses prn
   - maintain MAP goal of 60
   .
   # Rhythm: See above. Currently on NSR with LBBB without meeting
   criteria for ACS.
   - Holding beta-blocker for now given hypotension
   .
   # Pump: Patient with heart failure and EF of 25-30% after NSTEMI in
   [**Month (only) 1780**], now with EF of 15-20%, likely stunned myocardium.
   - pt unlikely to make meaningful recovery for ICH placement
   .
   # Coronaries: Pt with slightly elevated troponin secondary to arrrest.
   No ECG changes compatible for ischemia and negative MB.
   - Continue lipitor 80, ASA, plavix
   .
   # Anemia: Normocytic normochromic anemia with high RDW. Ferritin of
   1249, TIBC 226, TRF 174, Iron 30 in [**Month (only) **]/09 suggesting iron deficiency.
   Reticulocyte of 7.6 at that time (4.05 corrected and 2 with double
   correction) suggesting a component of acute disease with good marrow
   production. Reticulocyte count on [**2131-12-29**] low at 1.2; B12 and folate
   wnl. Transfused with one unit of pRBC on [**2131-12-30**] for hct 24 with
   response to 29.  Hct 26 today, secondary to hemodilution from IVF
   boluses.
   - follow hct [**Hospital1 **]
   - no transfusion
   .
   # Mitral regurgitation: Stable per TTE performed on [**2131-12-29**] compared to
   prior.
   .
   # Asthma: No wheezes or signs of exacerbation.  Patient has no
   spontaneous respiration, no albuterol needed.
   .
   # Gout: patient has impressive tophaceous gout R>L on the feet.
   - holding allopurinol in ARF

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of CAD, NSTEMI, HTN, and CHF. She has been admitted to the ICU due to VT arrest, septic shock, and multi-organ failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Neurological: The patient has a grave prognosis with irreversible hypoxic-ischemic brain injury and a large brain infarct. She has no brainstem reflexes and is not responsive to stimuli.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has heart failure with an EF of 15-20% and is on pressors to maintain blood pressure. She has a history of NSTEMI and is on aspirin, plavix, and statin.
* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a goal pCO2 of 27-30. She has coarse breath sounds bilaterally.
* Renal: The patient has acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 3.6 and is on dialysis. She has a history of kidney disease and is on lisinopril and spironolactone.
* Hepatic: The patient has liver dysfunction with elevated LFTs and is at risk for liver failure.
* Coagulation: The patient has a coagulopathy with rising PT, PTT, and INR. She is at risk for bleeding and is on heparin and FFP.
* Infectious: The patient has a severe c-diff infection with a heavy growth of staph aureus. She is on antibiotics and has a risk of sepsis.
* Metabolic: The patient has metabolic acidosis with anion gap acidosis and non-anion gap acidosis. She is on bicarbonate and has a goal pH of 7.35.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further deterioration of the patient's neurological status
* Development of septic shock or multi-organ failure
* Progression of liver dysfunction to liver failure
* Bleeding complications due to coagulopathy
* Development of respiratory failure or ventilator-associated pneumonia
* Further deterioration of the patient's cardiovascular status
* Development of acute kidney injury or need for dialysis
* Development of metabolic acidosis or lactic acidosis

Based on the patient's condition, the physician is likely to withdraw care and focus on comfort care measures.

   Mrs. [**Known firstname 1012**] [**Known lastname **] [**Last Name (un) **] is a very nice 76 year-old woman with

# Brain injury: Per neuro:
patient has irreversible hypoxic-ischemic [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) **]
[**Last Name (un) **] as well as a large brain infarct that was embolic.
  Patient was found down
 in rehab, unclear how long pt was out before she was shocked.  Patient was on a
rctic sun cooling protocol for 18hrs, and has been off sedation since [**12-31**] early
AM.  EEG shows global suppression, but given pt was on versed and in the presenc
e of renal failure, may need to wait until sedation completely wears off before
final neuro status and neurologic prognosis determined.  On the night of [**12-31**], pa
tient was noted to have anisocoria (right pupil 4mm minimally reactive to light,
 left pupil 2mm reactive to light), concerning for herniation.  Repeat CT head w
ith EEG leads on showed large MCA stroke.  Patient has no brainstem reflexes.
   - f/u on neuro recs
   - hyperventilation to reduce ICP, goal pCO2 27-30
   - keep HOB at 30 degree
   - hold off on mannitol given acute renal failure, acidosis, and
   hypotension
   - continue aspirin, plavix, statin
   - per patient's daughters, patient stated that she would not want to
   "live like vegetable"
   - will discuss with family today re withdrawal of care as there is no
   realistic expectation that pt will ever recover from this brain injury
   .
   # C. Diff colitis: Patient had diarrhea at rehab, and levofloxacin on
   admission did not help. It is very possible that when she was cooled,
   the c-diff pooled and was delivered in a large bolus upon rewarming.
   Patient was started on antibiotics for c.diff on [**12-31**], KUB in the
   evening of [**12-31**] shows evidence of early toxic megacolon. Pt meets the
   surgical indication for colectomy but not a surgical candidate given
   her brain injury and stroke.
   - continue PO vanc 500 mg q6, IV flagyl 500 mg q8 Flagyl
   - KUB stable, can hold off on serial KUBs
   - serial q4 abdominal exams
   - follow WBC and fever curves
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Patient with baseline Cr 1.4-1.5, admitted with
   Cr of 3.3 in context of poor PO intake on lisinopril and
   spironolactone, dirty U/A and c.diff infection which likely started
   when she was in rehab. Urine lytes suggestive of pre-renal etiology;
   creatinine improved to 2.4 with hydration. However, creatinine worsened
   on [**12-31**] with no UOP despite IVF boluses. Urine showed muddy brown casts,
   consistent with ATN.  UA consistent with pre-renal etiology.  No urine
   eos.  The etiology is multifactorial and related to sepsis/cdiff,
   intravascular dryness, and pressors.  UOP minimally responded to IVF
   boluses, low dose dopamine.  No HD will be initiated given poor neuro
   status.
   - f/u renal recs
   - trend lytes and renal function [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue to treat c.diff as above
   - continue to hold spironolactone & lisinopril
   .
   # Septic shock: likely secondary to c.diff infection.  Patient required
   pressor support with dopamine (up to 7) which increased with warming.
   The pressor was switched to Norepi (0.04) on [**2131-12-30**], switched to neo on
   [**12-31**] for tachycardia.  With multi-organ failure, including kidney,
   liver, and brain.
   - continue to wean her down on pressor
   - NS bolus prn
   - Holding ACEI and spironolactone and lasix for now
   - continue to treat c.diff as above
   - maintain MAP goal 60
   - cV02 goal >70%
   - follow lactate
   .
   # VF/VT Arrest: No strips from rehab, but was shocked by AED twice.
   Most likely etiologies for VF/VT arrest is renal failure/hyperkalemia,
   ischemia after NSTEMI in [**11-4**], and heart failure with EF 15-20%. 18
   hour Artic sun protocol commenced on [**2131-12-29**] AM, and completed at [**2131-12-30**]
   at 12 noon. TTE performed on [**2131-12-29**] demonstrated an EF of 15-20%, with
   akinesis of the LV inferior wall and basal to mid hypokinesis
   elsewhere, though the inferior wall akinesis was seen on prior ECHO on
   [**11-4**], likely representing stunned myocardium.
   - wean pressors as tolerates
   - will likely withdraw care today
   - no meaningful recovery will occur for ICD placement
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis: Both anion gap (gap 15) and non-anion gap
   metabolic acidosis (delta-delta <1).  Anion gap acidosis is likely from
   lactate acidosis and starvation ketone acidosis.  Non-anion gap
   acidosis is likely from diarrhea and NS she received yesterday. pH
   7.35, from hyperventilation on the vent.
   - continue hyperventilation on vent, keep pCO2 27-30
   - continue bicarb gtt at 75cc/hr
   - will likely withdraw care
   .
   # Coagulopathy: rising PT, PTT an INR.  Fibrinogen normal, less
   concerning for DIC.  Could be due to liver injury, however LFT is not
   terribly abnormal.   Also could be secondary to starvation and vitK
   deficiency.
   - hold off on IV vitK
   - continue to trend
   - will give FFP if actively bleeding
   - heparin sc discontinued, pneumoboots on for DVT ppx
   .
   # Liver dysfunction: LFT rising. AST, alk phos and LDH abnormal.
   Likely due to hepatic congestion, less likely shock liver since LFTs
   are not very high.
   - treat sepsis as above
   - continue to monitor
   - no RUQ US for now given this is most likely secondary to sepsis
   .
   # Leukocytosis with bandemia: secondary to c.diff.  UTI contributes to
   it as well. CXR no evidence of pneumonia.
   - continue to treat c.diff as above
   - f/u all cultures
   - continue to trend WBC and fever curve
   .
   # Lactic Acidosis: improving; related to low cardiac output and
   pressors. Feet are clearly hypoperfused (bilaterally)
   - continue to follow
   - NS boluses prn
   - maintain MAP goal of 60
   .
   # Rhythm: See above. Currently on NSR with LBBB without meeting
   criteria for ACS.
   - Holding beta-blocker for now given hypotension
   .
   # Pump: Patient with heart failure and EF of 25-30% after NSTEMI in
   [**Month (only) 1780**], now with EF of 15-20%, likely stunned myocardium.
   - pt unlikely to make meaningful recovery for ICH placement
   .
   # Coronaries: Pt with slightly elevated troponin secondary to arrrest.
   No ECG changes compatible for ischemia and negative MB.
   - Continue lipitor 80, ASA, plavix
   .
   # Anemia: Normocytic normochromic anemia with high RDW. Ferritin of
   1249, TIBC 226, TRF 174, Iron 30 in [**Month (only) **]/09 suggesting iron deficiency.
   Reticulocyte of 7.6 at that time (4.05 corrected and 2 with double
   correction) suggesting a component of acute disease with good marrow
   production. Reticulocyte count on [**2131-12-29**] low at 1.2; B12 and folate
   wnl. Transfused with one unit of pRBC on [**2131-12-30**] for hct 24 with
   response to 29.  Hct 26 today, secondary to hemodilution from IVF
   boluses.
   - follow hct [**Hospital1 **]
   - no transfusion
   .
   # Mitral regurgitation: Stable per TTE performed on [**2131-12-29**] compared to
   prior.
   .
   # Asthma: No wheezes or signs of exacerbation.  Patient has no
   spontaneous respiration, no albuterol needed.
   .
   # Gout: patient has impressive tophaceous gout R>L on the feet.
   - holding allopurinol in ARF
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NPO
   Glycemic Control:  insulin
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2131-12-29**] 05:30 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2131-12-29**] 09:50 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer:  IV famotidine
   VAP: bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: will likely withdraw care today as pt has no brainstem
   reflex
   Disposition :  CCU

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient, a 76-year-old woman with a history of CAD, NSTEMI, HTN, and sCHF, suffered a VT arrest and was found to have a large MCA stroke with loss of brainstem reflexes due to hypoxic injury. She was diagnosed with acute renal failure, septic shock, and metabolic acidosis, and was treated with antibiotics, IV fluids, and pressors. She also had a coagulopathy, liver dysfunction, and leukocytosis with bandemia.

The patient's condition is grave, with a poor prognosis for recovery. The neuro team has communicated to the family that the patient has an irreversible hypoxic-ischemic brain injury and will not recover. The family has been informed of this and has spent time processing the news.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.9°F)
* Heart rate: 83 bpm
* Blood pressure: 86/40 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Central venous pressure: 15 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 32.6 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 172 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 3.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 19 mg/dL
* Glucose: 118 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 13 mmol/L

The patient's medical complications include:

* Acute renal failure
* Septic shock
* Metabolic acidosis
* Coagulopathy
* Liver dysfunction
* Leukocytosis with bandemia
* Lactic acidosis
* Rhythm disturbances (atrial fibrillation)

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Supportive care for septic shock
* Antibiotics for c-diff infection
* IV fluids and pressors for hypotension
* Hyperventilation to reduce intracranial pressure
* Continuous monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results

The patient's prognosis is poor, and it is likely that she will not recover from her brain injury. The family has been informed of this and has spent time processing the news. Withdrawal of care is being considered, and the patient's code status is DNR.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient, a 76-year-old woman with a history of CAD, NSTEMI, HTN, and CHF, is in a critical condition with multiple medical complications. The patient's condition is as follows:

1. Brain Injury: The patient has suffered an irreversible hypoxic-ischemic brain injury with a large brain infarct, likely due to embolic stroke. She has no brainstem reflexes and is not responsive to stimuli.
2. C. Diff Colitis: The patient has developed C. diff colitis, which is likely secondary to her recent antibiotic use and cooling protocol. She has evidence of early toxic megacolon and is not a surgical candidate due to her brain injury and stroke.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, likely due to sepsis, c. diff infection, intravascular dryness, and pressors. Her urine output is minimally responsive to IVF boluses, and she has muddy brown casts consistent with ATN.
4. Septic Shock: The patient is likely in septic shock, secondary to c. diff infection, with multi-organ failure, including kidney, liver, and brain.
5. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate acidosis and starvation ketone acidosis, with an anion gap acidosis and non-anion gap acidosis.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient has rising PT, PTT, and INR, likely due to liver injury, starvation, and vitamin K deficiency.
7. Liver Dysfunction: The patient has liver dysfunction, likely due to hepatic congestion, with rising LFTs.
8. Leukocytosis with Bandemia: The patient has leukocytosis with bandemia, likely secondary to c. diff infection and UTI.
9. Lactic Acidosis: The patient has lactic acidosis, improving with low cardiac output and pressors.
10. Rhythm: The patient is currently in NSR with LBBB, without meeting criteria for ACS.
11. Pump Failure: The patient has pump failure, likely due to stunned myocardium, with an EF of 15-20%.
12. Coronaries: The patient has slightly elevated troponin, likely secondary to arrest, with no ECG changes compatible with ischemia and negative MB.
13. Anemia: The patient has normocytic normochromic anemia with high RDW, likely due to iron deficiency.
14. Mitral Regurgitation: The patient has stable mitral regurgitation, per TTE.

The patient's medical team is planning to withdraw care due to her poor neurologic status and lack of realistic expectation of recovery. The patient's family has been informed of the situation, and they are considering end-of-life care.
